questions.text: Out of a total of 2000 patients assessed for HIV, 200 were confirmed positive. A new ELISA screening test was conducted on the same group, identifying 260 positive cases, but only 130 of them actually had the disease. What is the specificity of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

93%The specificity based on the given clinical scenario is 93%.
Specificity refers to the test’s ability to correctly identify HIV-negative individuals (true negatives) out of all who do not have the disease. The formula for specificity is:
In the given scenario,
Total patients tested = 2000
True HIV-positive cases (confirmed) = 200

questions.text: Which health program does the DANISH international developmental agency support in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blindness

The Danish International Development Agency (DANIDA) assists in the development of services under the National Blindness Control Program.
DANIDA is Denmark’s development agency, supporting sustainable growth, poverty reduction, and humanitarian aid globally. It focuses on health, education, human rights, climate, and economic development, working with governments, NGOs, and organizations to build capacity, improve infrastructure, and expand healthcare in low-income countries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old healthy man presents with a history of small streaks of blood in his stools. Given that his father was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 56, his family physician recommends a colonoscopy. What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Secondary

Colonoscopy for early detection/screening of colon cancer is an example of secondary prevention. Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment is the component of secondary prevention.

questions.text: A total of 60 patients were diagnosed with COVID-19, out of which 12 cases of deaths were reported. Calculate the case fatality rate.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

20%
.

In this scenario, among 60 diagnosed COVID-19 patients, 12 deaths were recorded, resulting in a case fatality rate of 20%.
The case fatality rate is determined using the formula: (Number of deaths from a specific disease / Total number of cases of the same disease) x 100. Applying this formula: (12 deaths / 60 cases) x 100 = 20%.

questions.text: A study Initiated in 2012 at Delhi University with 5000-6000 individuals aimed to evaluate the role of physical activity and its impact on cardiovascular diseases was to be assessed in 2024. What type of study does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prospective Cohort Study

The preferred study type is a prospective cohort study, as participants were grouped based on their exposure to a risk factor-physical activity and then observed over time to determine whether the outcome, namely the impact on cardiovascular diseases, occurred or not.

questions.text: A patient hailing from Delhi prese”ts with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dengue

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of dengue fever. Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses (DENVs), consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), that are members of the Flaviviridae family, genus Flavivirus. Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a food adulteration disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Flurosis

Fluorosis is not classified as a disease caused by food adulteration.
Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana (Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.
Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:
Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L).
Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L).
Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L)

questions.text: The mosquito larvae in the image belong to the species:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A: Anopheles, B: Culex

The image shows A- Anopheles and B- Culex larvae.
Anopheles larvae lie parallel on water surface, lack a siphon, and are surface feeders. They lay eggs singly, have spotted wings, and transmit malaria. Culex larvae hang head-down with a siphon, lay eggs in clusters, and have unspotted wings with a hunched back. They transmit Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile, and viral arthritis.

choices.text: 1. Medical colleges and Hospitals, 2-CHC, 3-subcentre and PHC
1 CHC, 2 Subcentre, PHC, 3- Medical colleges and Hospitals
1-Subcentre and PHC, 2- CHC, 3-Medical colleges and Hospitals

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct arrangement for the levels of Health Care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1-Subcentre and PHC, 2- CHC, 3-Medical colleges and Hospitals
The correct arrangement for the levels of Health Care is as follows, Primary, Subcentre and PHC Secondary, CHC-Tertiary, Medical colleges and Hospitals.
The NPHCE was established for geriatric care and includes provisions at primary, secondary, and tertiary levels.

questions.text: In a class of 75 students, 80% received the measles vaccine. After one student contracted measles, 12 more students were infected due to exposure. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

86%

The secondary attack rate is 86%.
The secondary attack rate is calculated as (12/14) × 100 = 86%, meaning 86% of susceptible students exposed to the primary case contracted measles. Susceptibles are total students (75) minus immunized (60), minus the primary case, leaving 14.

questions.text: The mascot depicts Sapna, a local school-going girl who will play a role in spreading awareness within the community. Which National Health Program is associated with this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

National leprosy eradication programme

The given image is of Sapna, a mascot for leprosy awareness, associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP).
Sapna refers to a local school-going girl who will help to spread awareness in the community.

choices.text: Less incidence of Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio

questions.text: What are the benefits of transitioning from Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Less incidence of Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio

The benefit of transitioning from an Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to an Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) is IPV is unlikely to cause VAPP(Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio).
There are two types of vaccine that protect against polio: inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) and oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV).
1. Sabin (OPV)
2. Salk (IPV)

questions.text: Under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Project (IDSP), sentinel surveillance is conducted for which diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HIV, Hepatitis B

Under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Project (IDSP), sentinel surveillance is conducted for HIV and Hepatitis B.
IDSP is a national surveillance program aimed at early detection of outbreaks to enable timely response and monitor disease control efforts in urban and rural areas.

questions.text: Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for a population of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1000-2500

USHA will cover a population of 1000 to 2500.
She must be a woman who resides in the slum, preferably of age 25 to 45. This was a provision given by the National Urban Health Mission which was passed by the cabinet in 2013.

questions.text:
In a normal distribution, the mean value is 82 and SD is 1.5. Calculate the range of 2 SD.
SD-Standard deviation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

79 to 85

The range of 2 standard deviations for the given mean value is 79 to 85.
To determine the range within two standard deviations in a normal distribution, we use the formula:
Range= Mean ±2 x Standard Deviation (SD)
Given data: Mean = 82, Standard Deviation = 1.5.
2 SD mean +/- 2 SD.
Calculation:
Lower limit-82-(2×1.5)-82-3 = 79.
Upper limit=82+(2×1.5)=82+3=85.
The range within two standard deviations is 79 to 85. This means approximately 95.4% of the values in a normal distribution fall within this range.

questions.text: From the given flowchart, identify: A-the management technique used and B- the critical path.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A- Network analysis, B-Machinery installation

In the given image management technique, A is network analysis, and the critical path B is machinery installation.
Network analysis is a method to plan and manage complex projects by breaking tasks into interconnected steps, identifying the critical path (here, machinery installation in 10 months), and optimizing resources.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to OPD with a painless leg deformity and widening of the wrist. Further investigations show hypocalcemia, increased parathyroid hormone and hypophosphatemia with increased alkaline phosphate. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rickets

The radiograph shows the bowing of the legs of the child.
The most common cause of this deformity is rickets.
Rickets is a condition that affects bone development in children, leading to soft and weak bones due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It is commonly caused by inadequate sunlight exposure or poor dietary intake of these nutrients. Symptoms include delayed growth, bone pain, deformities like bowed legs or a pigeon chest, and dental issues.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Height for age
Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition.
Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry:
- Low height for age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population.
- Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition.
- High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
- Low weight for the age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.
Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for the screening of wasting in children.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is a child with a single palmer transverse crease and low-set ears most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aneuploidy
A child with a single palmar transverse crease and low-set ears is most likely to have Down syndrome and it is a type of aneuploidy.
Down Syndrome is a type of aneuploidy. It occurs due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), leading to a total of 47 chromosomes instead of the normal 46. This chromosomal abnormality causes the characteristic physical features, developmental delays, and health issues associated with the condition.

questions.text: What is the appropriate timing for taking a blood sample to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

72 hours after delivery
The appropriate time for taking a blood sample to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism is 72 hours after delivery.
After birth, there is a temporary elevation in TSH levels due to physiological neonatal surge, which remains elevated for the first 2-3 days of life. If sampling is done during this period, falsely elevated TSH values may be obtained. Therefore, the ideal time for sampling through a heel prick is after 72 hours of life.

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality will lead to cardiac arrhythmia in the case of severe vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypokalemia

The electrolyte imbalance most likely to cause arrhythmia in the setting of severe vomiting is hypokalemia.
Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.

questions.text:
What is the most appropriate diagnosis for a 3-month-old child presenting with cold, cough, and rapid breathing (RR 58/min) but no chest indrawing or danger signs according to IMNCI?
RR-Respiratory Rate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pneumonia

The clinical presentation of a 3-month-old child with rapid breathing, cold, and cough suggests pneumonia. However, since there are no signs of chest indrawing or other danger signs, it cannot be classified as severe pneumonia.

questions.text: A newborn child is having respiratory difficulty. The doctor evaluated and the child was found to have a posterolateral defect as shown in the CT image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bochdalek hernia

The clinical presentation of a newborn with respiratory distress and a posterolateral defect, as seen on the CT scan, suggests a diagnosis of Bochdalek hernia.
A diaphragmatic hernia occurs due to intrathoracic movement of the abdominal contents through a diaphragmatic defect. The types include:
- Bochdalek hernia (posterior): Most common type. Herniation occurs through the pleuroperitoneal foramen.
- Morgagni hernia (anterior): Herniation occurs through the foramen of Morgagni.

questions.text: A child presents with micrognathia and low-set ears. These clinical features are commonly associated with which type of genetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Deletion

The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with micrognathia and low-set ears is suggestive of cri-du chat syndrome, and it is associated with the deletion of chromosome 5p.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented for routine follow up of his anthropometric surveillance. He was found to be 90cms tall with a lower segment of 45cm. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options.
The U/L ratio is
- 1.7 at birth
- 1.3 at 3 years
- 1 after 7 years
- 0.9 in adults
Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia (SED) is a group of disorders of cartilage matrix proteins resulting in bone and joint disorders can be classified according to the defective proteins: collagens (types 2, 9, 10, 11) and the noncollagenous proteins. But is made up largely of type collagenopathies.

questions.text: A neonate has bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications and hydrocephalus. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Toxoplasma gondi

The characteristic triad of Congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Clinical manifestations apart from the triad include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, and mild thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A child with fused carpal bones comes to your clinic, diagnosed with hand-foot genital syndrome. What is the gene associated with hand-foot syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

HOXA13

In this case, a child with fused carpal bones has hand-foot genital syndrome caused by mutations in the HOXA13 gene, which regulates limb and genital development.

questions.text: A 4-week-old neonate was brought to the hospital with complaints of non-bilious vomiting. During the examination, the physician noted a firm, olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, which moved during feeding. What is the likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

: Idiopathic hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis show non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and visible gastric peristalsis from left to right. It’s common between 2-8 weeks, more in males, due to pyloric muscle hypertrophy causing gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text:
A four-year-old child has an upper arm circumference of 105 mm. On giving a trial of therapeutic food, the child accepted the feeds well. There is no edema seen on examination. What will be the diagnosis?
SAM- severe acute malnutrition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Uncomplicated SAM

In the given clinical scenario, a four-year-old child with an upper arm circumference of 105 mm who responds well to the trial of therapeutic food, indicating good appetite, is diagnosed with uncomplicated SAM.

choices.text: Isolate in the institution along with Vitamin A treatment
Home isolation of the child along with Vitamin A supplementation
Give MR vaccine, isolate the child and vitamin A treatment
Only Vitamin A supplement, no action needed for the rash

questions.text: An unvaccinated child from a migrant worker’s family presents with fever, sore throat, a characteristic red blotchy skin rash, and a Bitot’s spot in the right eye. What would be the appropriate management in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Isolate in the institution along with Vitamin A treatment

An unvaccinated child with measles and a Bitot’s spot likely has vitamin A deficiency, which worsens measles. Management includes isolation and vitamin A treatment, as deficiency causes eye issues and increases infection risk.

choices.text: Positive pressure ventilation with room air

questions.text: What is the immediate next step in the management of a 29-week gestation infant with a heart rate of less than 100/min and an oxygen saturation of 80% in the right upper limb?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Positive pressure ventilation with 21-30% 02

The immediate next step in managing a 29-week preterm neonate with a heart rate <100/min and SpO, of 80% in the right upper limb is positive pressure ventilation (PPV) with a bag and mask using 21-30% oxygen.

questions.text: An abdominal X-ray of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia reveals air in the bowel wall. What is the greatest risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prematurity

The above clinical scenario of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia, with X-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Prematurity is the greatest risk factor for developing NEC. NEC (Necrotizing Enterocolitis) is the most common life-threatening GI disorder in newborns, causing inflammation and necrosis, mainly in the distal ileum and proximal colon. Major risk factors include prematurity, formula feeding, and bacterial colonization.

questions.text: A child with a history of intubation presented to the OPD with shortness of breath while playing, approximately six weeks later. X-ray finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

The diagnosis in this child with a history of intubation and shortness of breath with X-ray showing the ‘steeple sign’ due to subglottic narrowing is acute laryngotracheobronchitis.
Acute laryngotracheobronchitis is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months to 6 years.
The clinical features includeincludee barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, and low-grade fever.

questions.text: cMYC gene mutation is seen in which of the following neoplasms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Burkitt’s lymphoma

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, characterized by the translocation of the c-Myc gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels.

questions.text: Patient underwent cholecystectomy and black pigmented gallstones were noticed. Which of the following is the least likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HbD Punjab

Pigmented gallstones are commonly found in chronic hemolytic syndromes such as sickle cell disease, HbH Disease, and beta Thalassemia Minor, but not in HbD Punjab.
Hemoglobin D-Punjab (HbD) is a common beta-globin variant from a point mutation, usually asymptomatic. It can coexist with other hemoglobinopathies like thalassemia or sickle cell disease, causing hemolysis, but alone, HbD does not cause hemolysis or pigmented gallstones.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man diagnosed with Huntington’s chorea has a family history of the disease. Which of the following best explains the earlier onset of the disease in successive generations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Genetic anticipation

Genetic anticipation causes earlier, more severe disease in successive generations, seen in disorders like Huntington’s disease, where CAG repeats in the Huntingtin gene (chromosome 4) increase over generations, leading to earlier onset of chorea and dementia.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Purkinje cell

The image shows a Purkinje cell in the cerebellar cortex—flask-shaped, located in a single layer between molecular and granular layers. It has upward dendrites in the molecular layer and downward axons terminating in deep cerebellar nuclei. Purkinje cells are inhibitory, using GABA.

choices.text: HBV infection in the recent past

questions.text: A patient tested positive for HBsAg, HBeAg and IgM Anti HBc. What is the status of the condition the patient is affected by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute hepatitis B

Positive HBsAg, and HBeAg with positive IgM anti-HBc antibodies correspond to acute hepatitis (early-phase, high infectivity)
HbsAg is positive only when the patient has an acute infection or a chronic carrier. Anti HBc antibody appear during acute infection and persists

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of persistent headaches. A CT scan of the head reveals a brain tumour. On histopathology, psammoma bodies are seen. Based on these findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Meningioma

A tumor with psammoma bodies suggests meningioma, a usually benign tumor arising from meningothelial cells of the dura or arachnoid, often attached to the dura or near the ventricular system.

questions.text: When is the best time to use TTC staining for clear visualization of myocardial necrosis after suspected infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2-3 hours

TTC staining best identifies myocardial infarction within 2-3 hours. Infarcts less than 12 hours old are not visible grossly, but can be highlighted by TTC, which stains healthy tissue brick-red. Infarcted areas appear pale due to loss of enzyme activity.

questions.text: Which is the type of cartilage present in the histology section given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hyaline cartilage

The type of cartilage shown in the above image is hyaline cartilage.
On microscopy, hyaline cartilage can be identified by:
- Presence of chondrocytes within lacunae.
- Group of two or more chondrocytes which are known as Isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests.
- Basophilic territorial matrix and pale interterritorial matrix
- Presence of perichondrium with outer fibrous and the Inner cellular layer

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in irreversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Large amorphous densities in mitochondria

Irreversible injury features large amorphous densities, vacuoles, and phospholipid deposits in mitochondria, indicating ATP loss. Severe damage involves calcium influx and flocculent densities, especially after reperfusion, leading to permanent cell death.

questions.text: In von Willebrand disease, what does vWF primarily bind to aid platelet adhesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gp1b/IX

The factor that von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to is Gp1b/IX.
Platelet adhesion is mediated by interactions between the platelet surface receptor glycoprotein IbGpIb/IX and vWF in the subendothelial matrix. Endothelial injury exposes vWF and causes the adhesion of platelets by the Gplb receptor.
Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) binding to ADP receptors (Option B) induces conformational changes in platelets. This change in glycoprotein IIb/Illa that occurs with platelet activation allows it to bind to fibrinogen, which leads to aggregation of platelets to each other and not to the endothelium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady with a history of long-standing goitre presented with a solitary thyroid nodule. Histopathological examination of the thyroid mass shows nests of polygonal cells and pink eosinophilic extracellular material. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Medullary carcinoma

The presence of nests of polygonal cells and pink eosinophilic extracellular material (amyloid stroma) on histopathological examination, makes medullary carcinoma of the thyroid the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient Is suffering from a rare disease with mitochondrial inheritance. This can be inherited from which of the following members?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mother

Diseases with mitochondrial inheritance are inherited exclusively from the affected mother.

Mitochondrial inheritance is maternal, as only the ovum contributes mitochondria. Both sons and daughters of an affected mother inherit the disease. Most mitochondrial DNA mutations affect RNA, causing muscle and neurological disorders like LHON, MELAS, and Leigh syndrome.

questions.text: Alpha-fetoprotein is a tumor marker used in the diagnosis and monitoring of various conditions. In which of the following conditions is AFP typically raised?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatoma

AFP is a tumor marker elevated in 50-70% of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), especially above 200 ng/mL. It aids in screening and monitoring treatment but is not entirely specific, as levels can rise in other liver diseases and germ cell tumors.

questions.text: A child is brought to your practice with distinguishable features such as obesity, hypotonia, and short stature. The parents of the child complained that he has an increased appetite with several episodes of binge eating. The child also suffers from developmental delays and intellectual disabilities. Karyotyping reveals microdeletion of the paternal copy of chromosome 15. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prader Willi syndrome

Paternal deletion of 15q12 is seen in Prader-Willi syndrome.
Prader-Willi syndrome is a type of non-Mendelian mode of inheritance and genomic imprinting disorder. It occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes. Deletion of the paternal chromosome occurs in 70% of the cases, in the rest, it is caused due to uniparental disomy where there are two copies of the silenced maternal gene with absent paternal genes. The net effect in uniparental disomy is the same as deletion.

questions.text: Identify the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lymph node

The image is that of a lymph node.
Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla.

questions.text: Flipping of which molecule occurs during apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phosphatidylserine

Phosphatidylserine (PS) is the molecule that flips out during apoptosis.
Phosphatidylserine (PS) is a phospholipid and a key component of the inner leaflet of cell membranes, playing a critical role in cell structure and signalling. It is particularly abundant in the brain, where it contributes to neuronal function, synaptic activity, and maintenance of the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern of a syndrome associated with ovarian fibroma, ascites, and pleural effusion that resolves after tumor removal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No inheritance pattern (non-hereditary)
The clinical vignette describes Meig’s syndrome, it is an acquired disorder without genetic association.
Meigs syndrome triad:
- Ovarian fibroma
- Pleural effusion
- Ascites that disappear after removal of the tumor
Meigs syndrome is mostly caused by ovarian fibroma. CA-125 levels may also be elevated. As it is a diagnosis of exclusion, a workup should be done to rule out malignancy. Exploratory laparotomy with surgical staging is the treatment of choice. Conservative surgery (salpingo-‘ oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

questions.text: All of the following drugs can be used in the management of hypertension in pregnancy except for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Enalapril

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is contraindicated in pregnancy due to risks like renal dysplasia, PDA, limb contractures, and other fetal malformations, especially in the second and third trimesters.

questions.text: During spermatogenesis, the process in which sperm cells develop from spermatogonia in the testes, the secretion of FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) in a male is inhibited by which factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Inhibin

The secretion of FSH in a male is inhibited by negative feedback effect of Inhibin secreted by sertoli cells. GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary to release FSH and LH. FSH promotes inhibin from Sertoli cells, which inhibits FSH. LH triggers Leydig cells to produce testosterone, which inhibits LH and GnRH, regulating reproductive hormones.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pathological heart sound seen during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diastolic Murmur

Diastolic murmur is considered to be a pathological change in pregnancy.
It is the ejection systolic murmur which is a physiological change.

questions.text: The earliest sign seen in pregnancy on ultrasound is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gestational sac

The earliest sonographic sign of pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac which is seen as the double decidual sign.
The double decidual sac sign (DDSS) is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualised. It consists of the decidua parietalis (lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (lining the gestational sac) and is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac.

choices.text: Ovarian mass with thin layer of endometrium
Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis
Empty uterus and adnexal mass with ground glass appearance
Trilayer endometrium without an adnexal mass

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature seen in ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

An empty uterus with an adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis is the sign most suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy.
A pregnancy is considered ectopic if implantation occurs at a site outside the uterine cavity. The majority of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube, the ampulla being the most common site.
The most appropriate management for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is single-dose methotrexate.

questions.text: Which part of the placenta is shown in this picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fetal side

Fetal side of the placenta is depicted in the picture
Placenta has two components-basal plate (the one on the maternal side) and chorionic plate (the one towards the fetal side which gives rise to the chorionic villi).
Usually, in a normal placenta, both basal and chorionic plates end simultaneously at the margin of the placenta.

questions.text: Identify the procedure being done.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intrauterine balloon tamponade

The given image shows an intrauterine balloon tamponade.

A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity and stop bleeding. It is used to manage refractory uterine atony. The insertion process requires two or three team members. First-person to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure. Another to place the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilize it. The third person instills normal saline to inflate the balloon, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL followed by further instillation over a few minutes for a total of 300 to 500 mL to arrest hemorrhage. Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter is generally removed after 12 to 24 hours.

questions.text: Identify the CTG pattern shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Early deceleration

The given CTG shows early decelerations. It is seen in fetal head compression.
In early decelerations, the onset, nadir, and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively.

questions.text: A patient underwent a forceps delivery a few hours ago and subsequently developed severe pain at the episiotomy site. Examination reveals vulvar swelling with bluish discoloration, along with hypotension (80/60 mmHg) and tachycardia. Which of the following should not be done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Remove the suture in ward

To remove the suture in the ward would be unadvisable since symptoms of hypotension and bluish discoloration of the vulva are indicative of a vulvar hematoma.
The vulva is the most common site for pelvic hematoma and the pudendal artery is the most common artery involved in vulval hematoma
Hematomas <5 cm can be managed conservatively with cold compress. Larger hematomas need to be explored surgically. And as the patient is already hypotensive, it suggests that hematoma is quite large in size. Hence trying to manage it in ward by removing the sutures can lead the hematoma to bleed profusely can cause further detoriation of patient’s condition and should be avoided. The next best step to manage it to resuscitate the patient in OT until she’ can be managed surgically.

questions.text: Identify this sign in pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hegar’s sign

The image dipicts Hegar’s sign.
Hegar’s sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and the fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.
This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

questions.text: The presence of edematous villi, a 46 XX karyotype, and negative p57Kip2 suggests a diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Complete mole

Edematous villi with 46 XX chromosome and a negative p57Kip2 immunostaining is suggestive of Complete Mole.
Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:
Complete moles:
- They occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes.
- In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46, XX karyotype.
- In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46, XX, or 46, XY.
- In complete moles, the embryo usually dies early in the development, and hence, cannot be identified.
- p57Kip2 immunostaining is negative.

questions.text: A female presents with hirsutism, delayed periods & obesity. USG findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome

The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound image given below showing an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery(a string of pearls) is indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: In developed countries, which kind of screening saved the most lives?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cervical cancer screening

Cervical cancer screening has been the most successful cancer screening program in medical history for developed countries.
According to WHO, widespread use of screening in high-income countries has resulted in a dramatic decline in cervical cancer mortality over the last three decades.
Moreover, IARC concludes that there is sufficient evidence that cervical cancer screening can reduce cervical cancer mortality by 80% or more among screened women.

choices.text: 3 months and after semen analysis is done
1 month and after semen analysis is done

questions.text: A man underwent vasectomy recently. The surgeon advises the patient to abstain from sexual activity for a certain period after the procedure before confirming the success of the vasectomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding the duration of abstinence post-vasectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

3 months and after semen analysis is done

Vasectomy is a permanent male sterilization involving ligation or clipping of the vas deferens, usually under local anesthesia via a small scrotal incision or no-scalpel technique. Men should abstain from sex for 3 months and have semen analyzed afterward. The procedure’s failure rate is about 0.15%.

questions.text: How much time delay should there be between the delivery of the head and delivery of the shoulder in the case of shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

60 seconds

Shoulder dystocia is defined as head to shoulder delivery time more than 60 seconds.
Shoulder dystocia, defined as a head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds, occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory respectively.

choices.text: Middle cerebral artery doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV)

questions.text: Which of the following is the best non-invasive tool for assessing fetal anaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Middle cerebral artery doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV)

Middle Cerebral Artery Doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) is the best non-invasive way of monitoring fetal anemia.
MCA PSV is used for the monitoring of fetuses of Rh-negative sensitized mothers, and if it exceeds 1.5 MoM and the gestational age less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling followed by transfusion is considered.
Serial measurements of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal MCA is reliable, noninvasive, and the recommended test to detect fetal anemia. Blood gets shunted to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. A rise in cardiac output and a fall in blood viscosity enhance the peak systolic velocity in the MCA.

questions.text: Identify the condition depicted in the laparoscopic image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Genital tuberculosis

The laparoscopic image shows miliary nodules on the uterus and peritoneum, indicating female genital tuberculosis (FGTB). Caused by M. tuberculosis, it usually spreads hematogenously from primary infection elsewhere, primarily affecting bilateral fallopian tubes, especially the ampulla, causing endosalpingitis. It most commonly affects women aged 20-30, with infertility being the main symptom.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is this instrument contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Obstructed labour

The image shows Piper’s forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is contraindicated in obstructed labour
Piper forceps is a specialized forceps, used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head of the breech (Option A). It can also be used in cases of occipito-posterior position and caesarian delivery (Options B and C). It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

questions.text: Identify the area highlighted in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rectovesical pouch

The area highlighted in the image points to the rectovesical pouch.
The peritoneum covering the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder in males, forming a rectovesical pouch. This is the lowest part of the peritoneal cavity in males and an important site for pelvic fluid collection.

questions.text: A nulligravida presents to the OPD with uterine prolapse. No cystocele or rectocele were noted. What procedure will you perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Abdominal sling surgery

For a nulligravid woman with uterine prolapse and no cystocele or rectocele, we will perform an abdominal sling surgery.
Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.
Abdominal sling surgeries: Young women desirous of retaining menstrual and reproductive functions are ideal candidates. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent.

questions.text: Following denotes which sign of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chadwick’s sign

The sign seen, giving a dusky bluish discoloration of the anterior vaginal wall is known as Jacquemier’s or Chadwick’s sign. The discoloration is due to local vascular congestion.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth. What is the first line management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lifestyle modification

The first line of treatment for this woman with signs and symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) such as irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth (hirsutism) is lifestyle modification.
PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. A weight loss of 10% through lifestyle modifications such as diet and exercise are considered first-line.

questions.text: Which hormone plays a major role in home based pregnancy tests?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Beta-HCG

Beta hCG, produced by placental syncytiotrophoblasts, is the basis of home pregnancy tests. It is a glycoprotein hormone with an alpha-subunit similar to LH, FSH, and TSH, and a specific beta-subunit measured in tests. Detectable in maternal blood 8 days after fertilization, hCG levels double every 48 hours early on, reaching 50,000–100,000 IU/L by 60-70 days. Levels then decline, reaching a minimum at 16 weeks, maintaining that level throughout pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the safest hysterectomy surgery to minimise the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vaginal Hysterectomy
Vaginal hysterectomy is the safest surgical approach to minimize the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table.
This is because the vaginal approach allows surgeons to follow natural anatomical planes and typically requires less dissection and manipulation of the uterus.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with irregular bleeding. Endometrial biopsy revealed endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. How would you consider treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Norethisterone

Progesterone therapy such as norethisterone followed by endometrial biopsy every 3 to 6 months is the best treatment in the case of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with the proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient with a history of obstructed labor and cesarean section presents with continuous dribbling of urine through vagina on day 7. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vesicovaginal fistula

The clinical scenario is suggestive of vesicovaginal fistula.
Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is an abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina, usually caused by obstetric injuries like prolonged labor or instrumental delivery. It causes constant urine leakage, leading to discomfort, pruritus, and skin excoriation. Obstructed labor can cause ischemic necrosis of the bladder base, resulting in a fistula after 3-5 days.

questions.text: A 26-year-old actor came with complaints of being unable to focus on his work. He worked for a short while in various occupations, before deciding he wanted to be an actor. After attending several auditions, he discovered that he was easily distracted, needed help remembering his lines, and even drifted off during reading. Identify the disorder in the given scenario.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

The disorder in the given scenario can be identified as Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition affecting children, adolescents, and adults around the world, characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention, and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. They often have significant impairment in academic functioning as well as in social and interpersonal situations.

questions.text: A lady came to the hospital after fighting with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

La-belle indifference

La-belle indifference is seen in conversion disorder. It is the absence of concern towards one’s problem despite the apparent severe disability.
Conversion disorder is also called functional neurological symptom disorder, and there is no bodily cause involved in this condition. A conversion reaction is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial stress. Most of the patients have a history of a traumatic event in childhood. The symptoms or deficits of conversion disorder are not intentionally produced. It is more commonly seen in females.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does the term ‘affective flattening’ imply?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Negative symptoms

Affective Flattening denotes the negative symptoms associated with Schizophrenia

questions.text: A doctor asks a patient about her age, and the patient responds, “You know doctor, I’m from a village, I was married at a very young age of 12 years and my husband was just 5 years older than me. Then I had two kids when I was around 18 or something. Now I am 38, but I look like their older sister”. What is most likely thought disorder displayed by patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Circumstantiality

Circumstantiality is a thought disorder where a patient provides irrelevant details before reaching the point, seen in schizophrenia, OCD, and dementia. For example, describing activities before explaining a bruise from a fall.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with a previous history of psychiatric disorder has become aggressive with neighbours. He is cheerful, speaking rapidly and also sleeping little. He exhibits hyperactive behaviour after discontinuing his prescribed medication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bipolar disorder (Manic episode)

The given clinical vignette showing increased activity, energy, and euphoria with a decreased need for sleep is indicative of an acute manic episode in the setting of bipolar disorder.
Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder, and mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and blood levels in excess of this may cause symptoms of toxicity. Therapeutic drug monitoring is done by measuring lithium levels 12 hours after the last dose.

questions.text: A lady presents to the hospital after having a fight with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her health status. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme responsible for formation of toxic metabolite
It neutralizes the free radicals produced by paracetamol

questions.text: A patient presented with paracetamol poisoning and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) was administered as an antidote. How does NAC prevent toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It replenishes glutathione levels

N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen overdose, restoring glutathione. Toxicity occurs when large doses produce NAPQI via CYP2E1, which is normally detoxified by glutathione. When glutathione is depleted, NAPQI binds to liver cells, causing hepatocyte necrosis and liver failure.

questions.text: A patient with penicillin allergy presents with fever, burning micturition, ototoxicity and dizziness. Which drug is most appropriate for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ciprofloxacin

In a patient with a UTI, penicillin allergy, ototoxicity, and dizziness, ciprofloxacin is the best choice. It’s a fluoroquinolone that inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, preventing DNA replication and cell division in bacteria.

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic man with a BMI of 31kg/m2 presented to the medicine department with concerns of gaining weight. All of the following anti-diabetic drugs can lead to weight gain except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Semaglutide

Semaglutide is an anti-diabetic drug that does not lead to weight gain.
Semaglutide is a recently approved oral GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) agonist drug used in the treatment of type 2 DM. It causes weight loss & its subcutaneous injection once weekly is approved for chronic weight management.

questions.text: Which adverse effect of bleomycin can be worsened by radiation therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pulmonary fibrosis

Pulmonary fibrosis, a known side-effect of Bleomycin can be exacerbated by radiation therapy.
Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic. It acts by generating free radicals by binding with a reducing agent (iron) in the presence of oxygen. This metal-drug complex cleaves the DNA of the tumor cell. It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and testicular cancer.

questions.text: A diabetic patient came with the complaint of pedal edema due to congestive heart failure and was prescribed a medication that is preferred in the setting of cardiac and renal failure. What is the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SGLT-2 inhibitor

In a diabetic patient with cardiac and renal failure, an SGLT-2 inhibitor like empagliflozin, canagliflozin, or dapagliflozin is used. These drugs block glucose reabsorption in the kidney, causing glycosuria, weight loss, blood pressure reduction, and offering cardiovascular and nephroprotective benefits.

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia was started on olanzapine therapy a few months ago. It was effective in controlling the symptoms, but the patient stopped taking this drug. What can be the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Weight gain

The patient likely stopped olanzapine due to its common side effect of weight gain. Olanzapine, an atypical antipsychotic, blocks serotonin and dopamine receptors, reducing schizophrenia negative symptoms. It causes fewer movement side effects but can lead to weight gain and metabolic issues due to serotonin blockade.

questions.text: Resistance to which of the following anti-tubercular drugs occurs due to mutation in katG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Isoniazid

Mutations in katG cause resistance to isoniazid (INH). INH is used with other drugs to treat TB; it is activated by katG, a catalase-peroxidase, to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis, killing the bacteria.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis was taking Indomethacin for pain. He was started on an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. What is the potential adverse effect that is likely to occur with this combination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hyperkalemia
A patient on indomethacin starting an ACE inhibitor is at risk of hyperkalemia, especially with renal failure or diabetes. Drugs that increase risk include NSAIDs, potassium-sparing agents, renin inhibitors, potassium supplements, and beta-blockers like metoprolol, which inhibit renin and shift potassium into the blood. NSAIDs also impair kidney function by reducing prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text: An epileptic patient presents with gum hypertrophy and dizziness. Which anti-epileptic drug is likely the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phenytoin

Gum hypertrophy and dizziness are commonly seen with phenytoin.
Gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) due to phenytoin therapy occurs due to tissue overgrowth secondary to altered collagen metabolism. The toothless portion of gums is not involved. It does not warrant discontinuation of the drug. It can be minimized by maintaining good oral hygiene.

choices.text: Increase in liver enzymes in the first 24 hours
N-acetylcysteine should ideally be started after 8 hours of ingestion

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the emergency department 6 hours after ingesting 5 paracetamol tablets. What is most likely progression seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increase in liver enzymes in the first 24 hours

Paracetamol toxicity is likely to lead to an increase in the liver enzymes in the first 24 hours.
Paracetamol is an analgesic and antipyretic with weak anti-inflammatory action. It is mainly metabolized in the liver by conjugation with glucuronic acid and sulfate and is excreted in the urine. The maximum dose of acetaminophen that can be given is 4 g/day.

questions.text: A male develops tightness In the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium during his trek towards a mountain peak. The drug prescribed for symptomatic relief acts of which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Proximal convoluted tubule

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, relieves acute mountain sickness by reducing HCO3 reabsorption in the proximal tubule, causing diuresis. Given before ascent, it’s effective for prevention. Side effects include paresthesia; bone marrow depression is rare. It’s contraindicated in liver disease.

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma is initiated on latanoprost ophthalmic solution 0.005%. Which of the following adverse effects of latanoprost should the patient be informed of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypertrichosis

Topical latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, reduces intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow. It is preferred over beta-blockers due to fewer systemic side effects. Adverse effects include blurred vision, conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening and darkening (hypertrichosis), iris pigmentation, and periorbital fat atrophy. It may also promote herpetic keratitis in patients with a history of herpes, especially if used preoperatively or in aphakic patients, and can cause cystoid macular edema following cataract surgery.

choices.text: Carboplatin is more neurotoxic than Cisplatin
Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than Carboplatin
Cisplatin causes more myelosuppression than Carboplatin
Carboplatin causes more ototoxicity than Cisplatin

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cisplatin and Carboplatin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than Carboplatin

Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than carboplatin due to its tendency to accumulate in proximal tubules, causing injury and inflammation. Carboplatin's stable structure leads to less renal accumulation and better excretion, making it safer for patients with kidney issues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a mass in the neck. Her T4 levels are high with decreased TSH. She undergoes thyroid ablation therapy using 1-131. What is the most likely adverse effect associated with 1-131 treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypothyroidism

I-131 is a beta and gamma emitter used for diagnosing and treating thyroid conditions, especially thyroid cancer. It targets thyroid tissue and differentiated cancers, destroying remaining tissue after thyroidectomy. The main side effect is hypothyroidism, which is managed with levothyroxine.

questions.text: Which of the following platinum based drugs are used in cervical cancer along with radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cisplatin

Cisplatin is the drug of choice for chemotherapy for cervical cancer. Chemoradiation (radiation plus cisplatin) is the main treatment for cervical cancer, improving survival and reducing recurrence. Post-treatment, patients need regular follow-up with exams, Pap tests, and imaging. The 5-year survival rate for stage IIB is about 58-63, depending on tumor size, lymph nodes, and health.

questions.text:
The risk of cancer that can be reduced with OCP use are all, except?

OCP- Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Breast Cancer

OCPs do not protect against breast cancer but reduce ovarian cancer risk by suppressing ovarian gonadotropin stimulation with long-term use.

questions.text: A 28 year female patient is under treatment of antipsychotic drug olanzapine for schizophrenia. She stopped the drug because of which side effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Olanzapine, an atypical (second-generation) antipsychotic, is well known for causing significant weight gain and metabolic side effects such as increased appetite, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance. In young female patients, cosmetic concerns like weight gain are a common reason for non-compliance or discontinuation of therapy.

Olanzapine has a high propensity for weight gain among antipsychotics, second only to clozapine.

questions.text: Headache patient, temporal region area pain relieved by triptans. diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery receives succinylcholine for muscle relaxation and later develops hyperthermia, rigidity, tremors, and tachycardia. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dantrolene

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.
Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

questions.text:
What is the newly added sixth link in the chain of survival according to the latest AHA update?
AHA-American Health Association
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Recovery and Rehabilitation

The newly added sixth link in the chain of survival according to the latest AHA update is Recovery and Rehabilitation.

choices.text: Stop aspirin to minimize perioperative bleeding risk
Stop metoprolol to increase cardiac output
Increase aspirin dosage for additional analgesic benefit

questions.text: A patient scheduled for elective hip surgery in 5 days is taking aspirin, a multivitamin, enalapril, and metoprolol. What is the appropriate perioperative management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Stop enalapril

In the given clinical scenario, where a patient is scheduled for elective hip surgery in 5 days and is taking aspirin, a multivitamin, enalapril, and metoprolol, the recommended perioperative management includes discontinuing enalapril, as it is an ACE inhibitor.
ACE inhibitors are discontinued 24 hours before surgery due to the risk of hemodynamic instability. ACE inhibitors block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), leading to vasodilation and reduced blood pressure. During anaesthesia, there is already vasodilation and decreased sympathetic tone combining this with ACE inhibitors can cause severe hypotension that is resistant to fluids.

questions.text: A patient in acute hypoxemic respiratory failure is administered oxygen using the device shown below. Name the device.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

High flow nasal cannula

The equipment shown in the image is a high-flow nasal cannula.
High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a mode of respiratory support used to manage conditions such as acute hypoxemic respiratory failure.
There are three components to a high-flow nasal cannula:
- A flow generator that provides a gas flow of up to 40 liters per minute
- An air oxygen blender that increases FiO2 from 21% to 100%
- A humidifier

questions.text: Soon after the administration of an epidural block with 1.5% lignocaine with epinephrine, your patient went into bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Accidental subarachnoid injection

Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea soon after the administration of an epidural block suggests accidental subarachnoid (intrathecal) injection resulting in total spinal anaesthesia.
Salient features of total spinal anesthesia:
- Occurs following attempted epidural/caudal anesthesia if there is accidental intrathecal injection
- Rapid onset, as the anesthetic required for epidural and caudal anesthesia, is 5-10 times that required for spinal anesthesia
- High spinal anesthesia extends to involve cranial nerves
- Accompanied by hypotension, bradycardia, apnea, and loss of consciousness

choices.text: Mucus secretions obstructing the endotracheal tube
Pneumothorax on the left side due to PPV

questions.text: What is the most likely cause when a patient under general anaesthesia develops left lung collapse after intubation, with breath sounds heard only on the right side during auscultation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right endobronchial intubation

The most likely cause of left lung collapse after intubation, with breath sounds heard only on the right side, is endobronchial intubation of the right main bronchus.
Endobronchial intubation is first indicated by a sudden rise in peak inspiratory pressure.
Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2 is the confirmation for an advanced airway placement, but it does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with lower urinary tract symptoms, including weak urinary stream, hesitancy, and nocturia. On digital rectal examination (DRE), a hard, irregular prostate is palpated. He has no significant past medical history but reports mild back pain over the past few weeks. The physician suspects prostate cancer. Which enzyme is elevated in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acid phosphatase

Prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) is commonly increased in prostatic cancer.

The form of acid phosphatase that is found in the prostate gland is called prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP). PAP is a glycoprotein that is synthesized by the epithelial cells of the prostate gland. It is secreted into the prostatic fluid, where it plays a role in the liquefaction of semen.
PAP is also a potential target for monoclonal antibody therapy. Sipuleucel-T is a cell-based approach to induce an immune response against prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) that is commonly expressed in prostatic cancer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the ER after sustaining an astride injury. Following the trauma, he experienced an urge to urinate but was unable to pass urine. On examination, blood was present at the urethral meatus. What is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bulbar urethra

The given clinical scenario with a history of an astride injury. Blood at the tip of the meatus, and inability to pass urine are all suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra.

Astride injury refers to trauma that occurs when a person falls with their perineum straddling a hard object, leading to blunt perineal trauma.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient was admitted following a road traffic accident. Paradoxical respiration was seen. His chest X-ray is shown below. He was given analgesics and oxygen was administered via face mask but he developed respiratory failure. What is the best line of management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mechanical ventilation

The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest flail’s chest.
It is characterized by contiguous rib fractures and paradoxical respiration following blunt trauma to the chest wall. Mechanical ventilation (like Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is the management of flail chest with respiratory failure.

choices.text: Monitoring the response to treatment in prostate cancer patients
Screening for prostate cancer in all men
Prognosis and survival of prostrate cancer patient
Confirming the diagnosis of prostate cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific clinical use of Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) in the management of prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Monitoring the response to treatment in prostate cancer patients

Monitoring the response to treatment is the most specific clinical use of PSA in prostate cancer management.
Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignancy in men above 65 years. The clinical features of prostate cancer are bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, arthritis, anaemia, and renal failure. Per rectal examination reveals a hard, nodular, irregularly indurated gland.
Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is useful in assessing the follow-up. PSA >10 ng/mL is suggestive of cancer and levels >35 ng/mL are diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. The prostatic biopsy is indicated when there is a raised PSA level or suspicion of prostate cancer.

questions.text: During a splenectomy for a 40-year-old patient with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), the surgeon must ensure the complete removal of all splenic tissue, including accessory spleens, to prevent symptom recurrence. Accessory spleens are commonly found in specific anatomical locations. Where is the most likely site the surgeon should search for an accessory spleen during the operation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Splenic hilum and mesentry

The splenic hilum and mesentery represent the most common location for accessory spleens.
An accessory spleen, a supernumerary spleen, a splenule, or a splenunculus refers to splenic tissue found outside the normal spleen. Around 10% to 30% of the population have accessory spleens; with an individual having one to six accessory splenic buds. Furthermore, the size of an accessory spleen can also vary. Most accessory spleens are approximately 1 centimeter but spleens larger than a few centimeters have also been observed.

choices.text: Vaccum assisted negative pressure wound therapy
Antibiotic irrigation of the wound followed by delayed primary closure
Initiating primary wound closure to reduce risk of further contamination

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient underwent an emergency laparotomy for grossly contaminated peritonitis due to a perforated hollow viscus. On postoperative day 7, the patient developed signs of wound infection, including erythema, tenderness, and serosanguinous discharge. Subsequently, the wound showed evidence of dehiscence with exposure of underlying tissues. The patient’s vital signs are stable, with no evidence of ongoing intra-abdominal sepsis. Considering the current wound status, what should be the most appropriate management strategy for the laparotomy wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vaccum assisted negative pressure wound therapy

The clinical scenario is suggestive of burst abdomen and the most appropriate management would be Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy.
Burst abdomen/Acute wound dehiscence is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration. It usually occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.
A sudden giving way feeling from the wound precipitated by bouts of cough, and pinkish serosanguinous discharge can be seen. Omentum or coils of the intestine are forced out of the wound.
Management includes delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag, placing a subcutaneous drain, suitable antibiotic therapy, and prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome as described above and VAC.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 3cm sub-areolar mass in her left breast. She reports bloody nipple discharge but denies pain, redness or systemic symptoms. On examination, the mass is firm and non-tender. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intraductal papilloma

The given clinical scenario of unilateral bloody nipple discharge with a palpable mass beneath the areola and histopathology showing a central fibrovascular core with papillae arborizing within the lumen are suggestive of a solitary intraductal papilloma
Intraductal papilloma is a benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It is defined as Localized hyperplasia of the ductal epithelium within the duct. According to the ANDI (Aberrations of normal development and involution of breast tissue) classification, it is an aberration of normal epithelial turnover. It comprises a central fibrovascular core and papillary projections of the epithelium and myoepithelial cells.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with prostate cancer. What is the mode of spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebra?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Venous

In prostate cancer, metastasis to the lumbar vertebra is through the Batson’s venous plexus.
Batson venous plexus is a valveless vertebral venous plexus communicating with the prostatic venous plexus. Carcinoma of the prostate metastasizes to the bone usually by the bloodstream through this Batson plexus. The bones most frequently involved are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage and skull are other common sites. Other routes of spread of prostate carcinoma are local spread to the seminal vesicles, bladder neck, trigone, and lymphatic spread.

questions.text: A patient presented with abnormally dilated, tortuous veins over the leg, clinically falling into C4a category. Which of the following is the correct treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Endothermal Laser ablation

The most apporpriate therapy for C4a category of varicose veins is endothermal laser ablation.
Varicose veins are subcutaneous dilated, tortuous veins 3mm or more in diameter. They commonly present with a sensation of dragging pain, heaviness, itching or burning over the affected area or the whole limb, and swelling of the feet. These symptoms increase throughout the day or with prolonged standing and are relieved by elevation or compression hosiery.

questions.text: Patient after head trauma responds to verbal stimuli with confusion, opens eyes to speech and follows simple commands and is able to localise pain. What is the GCS score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

12

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) for the given case scenario is 12.
GCS for the given case is 12 (E3 V4 M5).
E: eye opening to speech – 3
V: confused-4
M: localizes to pain – 5
GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.
Minimum GCS value: 3
Maximum GCS value: 15
The severity of head injury based on GCS:
Mild-13-15
Moderate-9-12
Severe-3-8

questions.text: A patient with grade 4 haemorrhoids underwent surgery. Identify the instruments used during the procedure from the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Haemorrhoids banding kit

The instruments depicted above are the components of a hemorrhoid banding kit.

choices.text: Forceful vomiting against a closed glottis

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. Chest X-ray showed the following findings. Which of the following episodes of vomiting corresponds to this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Severe retching with minimal vomitus
The clinical scenario of a 30-year-old patient presenting with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting with the inability to pass a nasogastric tube and a chest X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen is suggestive of gastric volvulus. It is associated with severe recurrent retching with the production of minimal vomitus.
Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.
Patients present with the characteristic Borchardt’s triad which comprises of:
Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
- Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
- Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube
Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

questions.text: A young male presents with a painless swelling in the right testis, which he noticed two months ago. On examination, the swelling is firm and non-tender, with no transillumination and the contralateral testis appears normal. An ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic mass in the right testis. Further imaging shows enlargement of the para-aortic and pre-aortic lymph nodes. Tumor markers, including AFP, B-hCG, and LDH, are elevated. The physician suspects testicular cancer. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

High inguinal orchidectomy

The clinical signs, along with elevated AFP, β-hCG, and LDH levels, indicate testicular cancer. The next best step is a high inguinal orchidectomy. Common features include a painless testicular lump, epididymo-orchitis, or acute testicular pain and swelling due to hemorrhage within the tumor. Spread to the abdomen may cause lumbar or abdominal pain, while lung metastases are often asymptomatic but can lead to chest pain, shortness of breath, or hemoptysis in advanced stages. Although the cancer commonly metastasizes to retroperitoneal lymph nodes, including pre-aortic nodes, biopsy of the scrotal mass or lymph nodes is generally not performed initially.

questions.text: For infants and children under the age of 2, which of the following samples are the best to diagnose UTI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suprapubic aspiration and urethral catheterization

For infants and children under age 2, suprapubic aspiration and urethral catheterization are the preferred methods due to their high reliability and minimal contamination risk.
Clinical features in UTI neonates include fever, vomiting, diarrhea, poor weight gain, and lethargy. If the child cries during voiding or has a weak urine stream with a palpable bladder, it implies urinary obstruction. High fever (>39°C), persistent vomiting, dehydration, renal angle tenderness, or raised creatinine is considered a complicated UTI.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Retrograde pyelogram

The image depicts a retrograde pyelogram.
Retrograde Pyelogram is particularly valuable when IVP/CT is contraindicated and excels at providing detailed imaging of the collecting system, especially for evaluating ureteral strictures and filling defects, making it especially useful in surgical planning.

questions.text: A patient presents with diffuse abdominal pain, and on examination, there is generalised tenderness along with board-like abdominal rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Perforation peritonitis

The given clinical scenario and the chest radiograph showing air under the diaphragm are suggestive of a hollow viscus perforation resulting in perforation peritonitis.
Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lactating female presents 2 weeks after delivery, with a 3 cm subareolar mass in her right breast. The mass is associated with redness, tenderness, and mild warmth. She reports no fever but mentions difficulty in breastfeeding from the affected breast. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lactation Mastitis

Lactational mastitis is a bacterial infection, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus, occurring during the first month of breastfeeding. It results from nipple cracks allowing bacteria entry, combined with inadequate milk drainage.

choices.text: Gangrene of the fingertip due to compromised vascular supply
Secondary infection requiring removal of the nail bed
Frog-like deformity of the finger caused by chronic inflammation and tendon dysfunction
Injury to blood vessels during wound cleaning leading to ischemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with persistent swelling and discomfort over the dorsal aspect of the index finger. He gave a history of penetrative trauma to the area a few days ago. On examination, there is a firm, tender mass with limited mobility of the distal interphalangeal joint. The image is shown below. If left untreated, what is the most likely complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Frog-like deformity of the finger caused by chronic inflammation and tendon dysfunction

In the given clinical scenario of penetrating trauma followed by swelling over the dorsal aspect of the index finger that could progress to a “frog-like” deformity, making this the correct answer.
