A “frog-like” finger refers to a Boutonnière deformity – a condition where the middle joint of a finger is bent inward while the tip joint is bent excessively outward, creating a distinctive appearance similar to a frog’s leg bent at the knee; essentially, the finger looks like it’s making a “buttonhole” shape.
The progressive tendon dysfunction leading to the frog-like deformity represents the natural history of untreated cases due to the anatomical relationship between the central slip of the extensor tendon and the dorsal aspect of the middle phalanx where the infection is located.

choices.text: Both superior and inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: During a laproscopic surgery while inserting a lateral trocar for surgery which of the following is most prone to injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Both superior and inferior epigastric artery

The most common source of bleeding during laparoscopic surgery is through both superior and inferior epigastric arteries.
These vessels run vertically in the posterior rectus sheath along the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle, creating a high-risk zone for trocar placement. The superior epigastric artery descends from the internal thoracic (mammary) artery, while the inferior epigastric artery ascends from the external iliac artery, and they anastomose within the rectus muscle. Their consistent anatomical location and the fact that they run in a relatively superficial plane within the anterior abdominal wall makes them particularly vulnerable during trocar insertion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient presents to you with severe pain and swelling of the left leg. He gives a history of sustaining a thorn prick to his left foot while hiking 5 days ago. The examination of his leg Is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cellulitis

The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of cellulitis.
Cellulitis is a painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by poorly demarcated areas of marked edema, dilated superficial capillaries, and extravasation of red blood cells and inflammatory cells into the dermis. Constitutional symptoms like fever and malaise are also present.

questions.text: A patient has multiple blood clots in the urine following a TURP procedure. Which catheter should be used for irrigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

22 French Foley’s 3-Way catheter

22 French Foley’s 3-Way Catheter is the most appropriate choice for this patient with blood clots after a TURP procedure.
The 3-way Foley catheter includes an additional channel for continuous bladder irrigation, making it essential for managing gross hematuria, post-prostate surgery care, and clot evacuation; this third channel allows for simultaneous inflow of irrigation fluid while maintaining continuous drainage.

choices.text: Presence of a pulsatile mass on physical exam

questions.text: A 61-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with back pain. He has been smoking for the past 30 years. On physical exam, he has an enlarged pulsatile mass over his abdomen. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is an indication for elective surgical repair in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Abdominal aortic aneurysm >=5.5 cm

The clinical vignette describing a smoker with abdominal/back pain, history of hypertension and smoking, physical examination revealing a pulsatile mass, and CT findings showing dilation of the abdominal aorta is indicative of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm is an indication for elective surgical repair of AAA.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing breast surgery. Some structures are being retracted during surgery. Identify the arrow-marked muscle in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Serratus anterior

The muscle marked by the arrow is the serratus anterior.
During a modified radical mastectomy, the boundaries typically seen include: clavicle superiorly, sternal border medially, the lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle (or the anterior margin of the latissimus dorsi) laterally and the inframammary fold inferiorly.
Injury to the long thoracic nerve can occur during radical mastectomy which paralyzes the serratus anterior muscle. This muscle can be tested by raising the arm above the head on the affected side.

questions.text: A 4-year-old-boy was brought to emergency department with complaints of acute radiating pain in right iliac region and during surgery the following structure was found. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Meckel’s Diverticulum

The clinical history and the image are both suggestive of Meckel’s Diverticulum.
Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum, which extends from the antimesenteric side of the small bowel. The diverticula which contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. It is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5-7 of gestation.

questions.text: A man was brought to the ER after being involved in a fistfight with a bartender, presenting with severe chest pain, dyspnea, distended neck veins, and hypotension (80/50 mmHg). He subsequently collapsed. On examination, percussion revealed hyper resonance in the infraclavicular region with absent breath sounds on the left. A chest X-ray showed a tracheal shift to the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tension pneumothorax

The X-ray shows a well-defined area without lung markings on the left, with tracheal and mediastinal shift to the right, indicating tension pneumothorax. This is a clinical emergency requiring immediate treatment, with imaging like ultrasound, chest X-ray, or spiral CT for confirmation. Tension pneumothorax occurs when a pleural tear acts as a one-way valve, causing lung collapse.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, his abdomen is tender in the epigastric region, and there is no palpable mass. Which of the following is the most specific and reliable marker for diagnosing acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serum lipase

The scenario is reflective of acute pancreatitis, the enzyme most reliable for the diagnoss is serum lipase.
Acute pancreatitis is diagnosed with clinical features plus elevated pancreatic enzymes, with amylase and lipase levels at least three times the normal to confirm. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific, especially after 48 hours, as amylase can be elevated in other conditions like peptic ulcer, mesenteric ischemia, salpingitis, and macroamylasemia.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old male who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the bile duct was injured. The area of injury is shown in the image below. Which type of bile duct injury does this belong to, according to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type A

The image shows a cystic duct stump bile leak, classified as Strasberg type A. Bile leaks are common at the cystic duct post-cholecystectomy. MRCP is the gold standard for biliary anatomy, and combined with magnetic resonance angiography, it detects vascular injuries. HIDA scan confirms bile leaks or obstructions.

questions.text: A patient received a tubal block and is scheduled for laparoscopy. Identify the instrument used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Veress Needle

Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery.

questions.text: Identify the part marked ‘A’?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Edge
The edge of an ulcer is is represented by ‘A’
An ulcer is defined as a break in the continuity of the epithelium or mucous membrane with molecular death.
Classically an ulcer is described to have four parts which are:
1. Margin
2. Edge
3. Floor
4. Base

questions.text: A patient presented with the lesion shown in the image. Which of the following will have least priority in calculating the prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Duration

The given image dipicts a patient with carcinoma of the lower lip and most likely has a squamous cell carcinoma of the lip. Duration of the lesion will not have any affect on the prognosis.
The factors that affect prognosis are:
1. The biological behavior and histological grade 
2. Extent or depth of invasion 
3. Anatomical considerations like the site of the lesion 
Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 70 years old but can be seen in younger patients. Risk factors include sunlight exposure, smoking, and tobacco use. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a painless, rapidly growing, well-defined, mobile breast lump shows a leaf-like pattern with stromal overgrowth on biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phyllodes tumor

Biopsy shows increased stromal cellularity with leaf-like architecture, indicating a phyllodes tumor. Usually benign, it presents as a large, bosselated, mobile breast mass, often in women over 40, without skin infiltration or nipple retraction.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cystic artery

In the given image the marked structure is the cystic artery.

The image below mentions the boundaries of Calot’s triangle and cystic artery.

questions.text: An old person presented with an ulcer on the medial canthus with pearly and rolled margins. Histopathology shows nesting cells with peripheral palisading patterns. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Basal cell carcinoma

This patient, presenting with an ulcer on the medial canthus with pearly, rolled margins, and histopathology revealing nesting cells with peripheral palisading, is most likely diagnosed with basal cell carcinoma.
Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a slow-growing, locally invasive skin tumor from basal epidermal cells, causing deep tissue destruction (rodent ulcer). It does not spread via blood or lymph. UV exposure is the main risk factor, typically affecting sun-exposed areas like the nose, face, and inner eye canthus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a slow-growing, painless mass in her left breast. On physical examination, the mass is soft, well-circumscribed, and mobile. A biopsy is performed, and histopathology reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Colloidal carcinoma

The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of colloid/mucinous carcinoma of the breast. Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast cancer with mucin deposits. Intracellularly, nuclei are pushed to the periphery, forming signet ring cells; extracellularly, tumor cells are in clusters within mucin lakes.

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with respiratory distress, cough, unable to speak after eating. What is next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A carpenter presents with bilateral knee pain and fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee. There is inflammation and tenderness over his knee. MRI of knee is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Housemaid Bursitis

The fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee as well as the image, both suggest Housemaid Bursitis.
Housemaid’s knee is nothing but prepatellar bursitis and is seen in the lower half of patella and upper half of ligamentum patella. Suprapatellar bursa always communicates with the knee joint.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented to OPD with the given presentation. On examination, it seems gelatinous in consistency. She reports fluctuation in size, mild numbness in hand and occasional pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Ganglion cyst

The history and image are suggestive of a patient with a ganglion cyst.
Ganglion cyst arises from the leakage of synovial fluid from a joint or tendon sheath and thus contains a glary, viscous fluid.
It can appear anywhere in the wrist but the most common area is the dorsal surface of the scapholunate ligament.
Patients usually present with painless, well-defined, cystic, transillumination-positive, and non-tender swelling. If there is an impingement on a nearby nerve or structure it can cause pain.
It disappears spontaneously, but the aspiration of the swelling or operative removal can be done for reassurance or when there is pressure on the nerve. Even if treatment is done, the rates of recurrence are high.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency room following a bike accident. Examination reveals the right upper limb in abduction and external rotation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anterior Dislocation of the Shoulder

The upper limb in abduction and external rotation and radiograph are both suggestive of anterior dislocation of the shoulder.
The AP view radiograph shows the disturbed articulation between the humeral head and glenoid fossa. The humeral head is seen below and medial to the glenoid socket. This suggests anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint. In young adults, the common cause for anterior dislocation is athletic injuries, while in older adults, falls are a more common cause.

questions.text: Identify the type of epiphysis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Pressure Epiphysis

The image depicts the distal end of the tibia which is an example of a pressure epiphysis.
The distal tibial epiphysis, near the ankle joint, is a pressure epiphysis because it primarily bears weight and compressive forces rather than muscular forces.
Pressure epiphysis is articular in nature and takes part in the transmission of weight. Examples are the head of the femur, the lower end of radius, etc.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to ER after a car accident. He had multiple injuries and a femoral shaft fracture. He was treated and stabilized. But 48 hours later, he suddenly develops breathing difficulty, increased heart rate and petechial rashes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fat embolism

History of sudden onset breathlessness and rashes on 3rd day of admission after femoral shaft fracture should raise suspicion of fat embolism.
Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma.
Pathogenesis-release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats and actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

questions.text: A person presents with complaints of clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers. Along with it, there is sensory loss at tips of these fingers. What structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ulnar nerve

The given description is of a clawing of 4th and 5th finger with loss of sensation in the tips of these fingers are classically seen in case of an ulnar nerve injury.
The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints. Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers.

questions.text: Identify the type of splint.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bohler Braun splint

The given image shows Bohler Braun splint used for unilateral leg traction.
- The proximal pulley is used to prevent foot drop.
- The 2nd pulley is used for traction in line with the hip.
- The 3rd pulley is used for traction in line with foot.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with a bone tumor showing a sunburst appearance on imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Osteosarcoma

A bone tumor with a sunburst appearance on imaging is most likely osteosarcoma.
Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.
In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman’s triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

questions.text: A person presents with complaints of numbness, tingling and paresthesias of the thumb, index finger and middle finger. There is numbness at the dorsum of the base of the thumb as well. What structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Median nerve

Patient presents with pain and paresthesia over the lateral 3 and a half digits and numbness at the dorsum of the base of the thumb, both of which are indicative of a median nerve injury.
There may be weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted. Carpal tunnel syndrome is a common cause and can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.
